title: Dan Blaine
text:
Daniel Blaine (1891–1958) was a professional <a href="American%20football">football</a> player for the <a href="Staten%20Island%20Stapletons">Staten Island Stapletons</a> from 1915 until 1924. In 1915 he, along with three other players, formed the team to play other <a href="semi-professional">semi-pro</a> teams from <a href="New%20York%20%28state%29">New York</a> and <a href="New%20Jersey">New Jersey</a>. He suspended his football career in 1918 to serve in the <a href="United%20States%20military">United States military</a> during <a href="World%20War%20I">World War I</a>. Once the war ended, Blaine took over sole ownership of the Stapletons. He stayed in the Stapleton lineup at <a href="Halfback%20%28American%20football%29">halfback</a> until ending his playing career in 1924 at age 33. After his retirement from football, Blaine focused solely on owning and managing the team.
After a November 14, 1926 33–0 loss to the <a href="Newark%20Bears">Newark Bears</a>, Blaine promptly hired most of the Newark players, including star rookie <a href="Doug%20Wycoff">Doug Wycoff</a>, who were still owed money by the Bears due to the team's financial problems. As a result, the Bears went out of business, while the Stapletons benefited from Newark's folding. In 1929, the Stapletons became members of the <a href="National%20Football%20League">National Football League</a> after the <a href="New%20York%20Yankees%20%28NFL%29">New York Yankees</a> folded. This resulted in a rivalry between the Stapletons and the <a href="New%20York%20Giants">New York Giants</a>. While the Stapletons never had a winning season in the NFL, they did manage to defeat, or tie some of the teams that are still in existence today.
A combination of the <a href="Great%20Depression">Great Depression</a> and having too small of a stadium that could have never accommodated enough fans to make the team profitable caused great financial difficulties for the team. Many of the Stapletons' fans couldn't afford tickets to make a team possible. Blaine went through the formality of getting NFL permission to suspend league operations for the <a href="1934%20NFL%20season">1934 season</a>. The team played one more season of semi-pro football in 1934 before quietly folding. In June 1935, Blaine's franchise was finally declared forfeit.
Restaurants.
Blaine also owned several restaurants on <a href="Staten%20Island%2C%20New%20York">Staten Island</a>. However, it is rumored that some, if not all, of these restaurants were really <a href="speakeasies">speakeasies</a>, that illegally served alcohol during the period of <a href="History%20of%20the%20United%20States">United States history</a> known as <a href="Prohibition%20in%20the%20United%20States">Prohibition in the United States</a>. One of Blaine's restaurants was located next to the Stapletons' home field, <a href="Thompson%20Stadium%20%28Staten%20Island%29">Thompson Stadium</a>.
